articles.title: German Ski Instructor Confirms Japan Fully Lives Up To The Hype
articles.description: Quast's journey began in Tokyo before hopping in a rental car and making his way to Hakuba Happo-One, arguably the most famous ski resort in the region.
articles.content: German ski instructor turned social media influencer Marius Quast has gained a substantial following reviewing ski resorts across Europe. In his latest video he made his first sojourn to Japan to see if skiing the Hakuba Valley will live up to its legendary status. Quast’s journey began in Tokyo before hopping in a rental car and making his way to Hakuba Happo-One , arguably the most famous ski resort in the region. Happo-One played host to the 1998 Winter Olympics and is considered the most alpine area in the Hakuba Valley with long runs, challenging slopes, a true alpine feel. Quast then popped over to Hakuba Cortina famous for its dense forest and deep powder, otherwise known as called Japow. The juxtaposition of the mountains is notable and its well worth checking both out for yourself. Beyond the incredible skiing, Quast was taken back by the Japanese society and culture: “Japan feels different. Calmer. More structured. More respectful. And at the same time, incredibly fascinating

articles.title: 40 Evacuated After Chairlift Malfunction in Minnesota
articles.description: Rescuers focused on getting kids and more vulnerable people down first before fully evacuating the 40+ stranded guests.
articles.content: Dozens of skiers and snowboarders were treated to complimentary pizza and hot chocolate after requiring evacuation from a chairlift at Lutsen Mountains in northern Minnesota in the midst of bitter cold and windy conditions. Bring Me The News reports fire crews and ski patrol responded to scene at around 9:30am on Saturday morning when the chairlift malfunctioned in 56+mph winds and subzero temperatures. Rescuers focused on getting kids and more vulnerable people down first before fully evacuating the 40+ stranded guests. “Three crews went to work once it was determined the lift was not a quick fix. One patrol group from the bottom, the fire department and lift ops in the middle over the road with a ladder truck and glider chairs, and another patrol group from the top. With the persistent high winds that picked up further, there were great challenges shooting the rope between the lift wires and over the cable.” – Andrew Schultz The rescue operation lasted around 5 hours with some guests

articles.title: You Really Don’t Want To Fall On The Steepest Ski Trail In The United States
articles.description: This is what it looks like to fall on Rambo, the steepest man-made tree-cut ski trail in the United States.
articles.content: There are a lot of notoriously steep ski trails int he United States, but no man-made/tree-cut ski run in the country can beat Rambo at Crested Butte Mountain Resort . As the steepest in-bound tree-cut run, Rambo offers a consistent 55-degree pitch with exposed rocks, trees, and major moguls. If the features weren’t enough to make you turn away, know that even the resort’s ski patrol often admits that the conditions are basically never good. With all that combined, you can probably imagine that wiping out isn’t the best move, but this video really makes it evident. A wipeout on Rambo often means sliding all the way to the bottom, potentially losing your skis and requiring a hike back up in the process. If you’re hoping to hit the steepest man-made run in the United States, make sure you understand your limits and do so with caution. Once you start, there’s very little ability to bail. articles.title: Le Massif Cancels Remainder Of 2026 Ski Season Amid Labor Dispute
articles.content: Le Massif de Charlevoix has announced it will not reopen for the remainder of the 2025-26 ski season, citing an impasse in contract negotiations with its unionized workforce that has been on strike since early January. The decision comes after 300 employees represented by the Syndicat des travailleuses et travailleurs du Massif rejected both a final contract offer and a management proposal to submit the dispute to binding arbitration. The resort, considered one of eastern North America's premier ski destinations, had warned that continuing operations beyond the end of January would be impossible without a resolution. The final decision came after the Syndicat des travailleuses et travailleurs du Massif (affiliated with the CSN) rejected management’s latest contract offer and a proposal to enter into binding arbitration. According to Groupe Le Massif, the timing was critical. Management stated that a return to work was required by January 20 to complete essential artificial snowmaking.

articles.title: Wisconsin Skier Sets Record For Longest Continuous Rope Tow Lap (16.5 Hours/218.79 Miles)
articles.description: 28 participants began the challenge but only 15 spent the full 16.5 hours riding the Valhalla rope tow.
articles.content: Dresser, WI — On January, 9th, 2026 skiers and snowboarders up in Wisconsin set out on a unique challenge when they looped the legendary rope tow at Trollhaugen Ski Resort from 10:00am to 2:30am in what they have deemed the “Longest Lap” contest. 28 participants began the challenge but only 15 spent the full 16.5 hours riding the Valhalla rope tow. After full day of skiing that went well into the night, skier Nick Drye came out on top with an incredible 218.79 miles skied. While this achievement in endurance skiing and snowboarding was not officially recognized by Guinness World Records but the resort plans on getting an official adjudicator to witness the feat the next time they hold the event. Snowboarder Jayva Jordan scored 217.71 miles with 777 laps. articles.title: Quebec Ski Resort Will Close For The Season If No Agreement Reached With Union
articles.description: Today, unionized workers voted against a proposed agreement that would have ended the strike at the Quebec ski resort.
articles.content: Quebec — The season could end soon for one of Quebec’s (and Canada’s) best ski resorts. On January 2nd, workers at Le Massif voted to go on strike. The Massif Workers’ Union is part of the CSN. The workers are seeking better pay, more vacation and sick time, and better safety measures. In response, the ski resort shut down beginning on January 3rd. The ski resort reopened on January 6th, but only with limited terrain. This past weekend, the situation escalated by a couple of notches. In a press release shared to media outlets, Le Massif stated that if no deal is reached by January 20th, they will shut down operations for the 2025-26 season. “Le Massif de Charlevoix needs to know the position of the union and employees quickly. articles.description: In a podcast episode of The Tosh Show, he interviews Bandit Ferrante, a lead snow groomer at Palisades Tahoe.
articles.content: Tahoe — Did you know that comedian Daniel Tosh is an avid skier? One such example is his home, which is for sale and includes its own ski slopes. Then there’s the fact that he loves going to Palisades Tahoe. In this episode of the Tosh Show , he interviews Bandit Ferrante, Grooming Assistant Manager at Palisades Tahoe. Daniel Tosh actually asked many great questions to Bandit, as Ferrante is able to explain the complexities of his job. Even if you’re an avid skier or idler, you may learn a thing or two from the interview. articles.content: As we head into one of the busiest extended ski weekends of the season, its important to remember you manners at all times. The Garnet, Ruby, Sapphire, and Diamond Bowls on Blackcomb Mountain at Whistler Blackcomb offer some seriously incredible expert-only terrain with hairy cliffs, chutes, and other wild features. To access these bowls, skiers and snowboarders travel through Spanky’s Ladder, a choke point that, in extreme cases, can create quite a terrifying crowd. Apparently some skiers and snowboarders decided they were too good to wait in line on a busy day, riding ahead and forging their own path. articles.content: The top of Camelback Mountain. | Image: SnowBrains Conditions report from Tuesday, January 13. Camelback Mountain Resort is located in the Pocono Mountains and is one of the biggest resorts in Pennsylvania. It is a great day trip from NYC, which is approximately 1 1/2 hours away, and also only 2 hours away from Philadelphia. Its proximity to these two major cities makes it a great ski destination as the only ski-in-ski-out mountain in the Poconos. The weather conditions on the mountain were great in the morning with clear, sunny skies, no wind, and temperatures in the upper 30s. It did rain in the region over the weekend, but there were no signs of the precipitation on Tuesday: there were no bare spots, and the slopes were perfectly groomed. The mountain was in great shape and had a base depth of 16 to 36 inches, with seven lifts running, and all of its 39 trails open. articles.description: In a sign of the West's rough winter, Vail Resorts ski season metrics dropped sharply compared to the start of the 2024-25 season.
articles.content: Broomfield, Colorado — If recently released metrics from Vail Resorts are any indication, it could be the worst winter in modern history for the U.S. ski industry. Yesterday, Vail Resorts announced its skier metrics for the first portion of the 2025-26 season. The metrics aren’t pretty. Skier visits are down 20% year over year. Other reported metrics include dining revenue down 15.9%, ski school revenue down 14.9%, and retail/rental revenue diminishing by 6.0%. The least-horrible metric is lift ticket revenue, which is down only 1.8%. Here’s what Vail Resorts CEO Rob Katz said regarding the start of the 2025-26 ski season: “We experienced one of the worst early season snowfalls in the western U.S. in over 30 years, which limited our ability to open terrain and negatively impacted visitation and ancillary spending for both local and destination guests during the period. articles.title: Massive Avalanche Sends Onlookers Fleeing At Russian Ski Resort
articles.description: Huge avalanche engulfs parking lot at Russian ski resort.
articles.content: Kabardino-Balkaria, Russia — Unnerving footage from Elbrus Ski Resort in Kabardino-Balkaria, Russia where a massive avalanche came crashing down the slopes engulfing the parking lot in a powder cloud and sending onlookers fleeing. Holy shit, this morning this is scary! A massive avalanche struck the Elbrus Resort in Kabardino-Balkaria, Russia on January 15. pic.twitter.com/cl0RxbvlWS — Weather Monitor (@WeatherMonitors) January 15, 2026 The slide occurred yesterday January, 15, 2026. articles.content: Saskatchewan — Similar to the American Midwest, Saskatchewan isn’t known for its ski areas. However, there is one mountain with decent skiable acreage that is now abandoned. In Skier72’s latest episode of The Lost Resorts series, he breaks down the history of Ochapowace. The video analyzes the history of the ski resort, why it closed, what it looks like today, and how it skied. Click here to watch more episodes of his series. History of Ochapowace Situated less than two hours from Regina, it was operated by four First Nations’ tribes. It first opened in 1968 as a modest rope tow operation and grew in the 1970s. articles.title: New Hampshire Ski Area Opens New Lift For First Time In Decades
articles.description: An under-the-radar ski area in New Hampshire has added a new surface lift to improve the beginner experience.
articles.content: Franklin, New Hampshire — It’s been a couple of years of evolution at the Veterans Memorial Recreation Area . The ski area installed a snowmaking system a few years ago and has grown its offseason activities thanks to a dedicated team of mountain bike trail builders. The latest addition, which will help grow the skiing experience, debuted earlier this month. A few weekends ago, The Vets debuted a new magic carpet. Previously, new skiers and riders had to ride the rope tow or T-Bar to access the slopes, which is a tricky introduction to the sport. This magic carpet allows for easy learning and simple loading and unloading. The opening comes as the ski area faces fundraising challenges. There’s this project that they’re raising funds for, as well as the planned T-Bar replacement due to the age of the current one. You can support the Vets by donating here . articles.title: Massive Buck Sprints Past Ski School Kids @ French Ski Resort
articles.description: Red Deer blasts through powder and sprints past ski school kids.
articles.content: Incredible footage from the French Pyrenees where a group of ski schoolers had a close encounter with a Red Deer buck on the slopes of Val-Louron Ski Resort . Red deer thrive across much of Pyrenean, especially in mid to high elevation valleys . Adult male red deer, like the one featured in the below video, stand roughly 4.5 feet tall at the shoulder and can reach around 550 pounds in favorable enviormental conditions. These powerful cervids usually avoid people and can be dangerous at close range (especially during the autumn rut) . Thankfully this buck was more concerned with high tailing it across the ski trail than in the approaching children in the ski school. View this post on Instagram A post shared by ESF Val Louron (@esf_val_louron) Red deer commonly shift activity toward crepuscular or nocturnal periods to avoid disturbance when cohabitating with humans but encounters can and still do happen. articles.title: How Telluride Is Doing This Week Following The Ski Patrol Strike
articles.description: Businesses are still seeing the impacts of the ski patrol strike, while the ski resort is slowly growing its open terrain and lifts.
articles.content: Telluride, Colorado — We’re approaching MLK weekend, which is one of the critical periods for ski resorts. While many locals in ski towns dread the crowds, locals in Telluride are hoping that people show up. Last Thursday , the Telluride Ski Patrol Union reached an agreement with the ski resort. The ski resort began growing its trail and lift count on Saturday. But how are the ski resort and the area doing now? CBS Colorado reported earlier this week that businesses are still struggling despite the ski resort gradually opening up more terrain and lifts. articles.title: It’s Been A Deep And Deadly Week In The European Alps
articles.description: David Webster of Chamonix Ski Bum is back with another ski conditions roundup for the European Alps, and it was a deep one for many regions.
articles.content: David Webster of Chamonix Ski Bum is back with another ski conditions roundup for the European Alps, and it was a deep one for many regions. Unfortunately those deep conditions brought their own danger, with quite a few avalanche deaths occurring throughout the mountain range in the past week. The northern and western Alps saw up to a meter, or a little over 3 feet, in a 3-4 day span from Wednesday through Saturday. It wasn’t the biggest storm of the season, but it brought some exceptional conditions. The best snow was found in Savoie, Les 3 Vallées, the Chamonix area, and parts of Switzerland and Austria. Unfortunately the conditions in the Dolomites weren’t quite as good. Warm temperatures and wind transformed much of the snow by Monday and Tuesday, turning much of the powder into crusty or slushy conditions. articles.title: Why Utah’s Ski Boom Could Be Going Bust
articles.description: A new podcast episode features interviews with ski industry and weather experts to discuss whether Utah's best shredding days are behind it.
articles.content: Utah — It’s historically the worst winter on record in Utah. That’s not a hyperbole, as many snowpack sites in Utah have now recorded their worst-ever January totals . Does this mean that Utah’s ski boom is going bust? The health of Utah’s ski industry was discussed on a RadioWest KUER 90.1 podcast episode this week. As part of the podcast, they interviewed Joe Prokop (longtime Alta passholder), Sam Weintrub (Co-Founder of PeakRankings), and Glen Merrill (SLC meteorologist with the National Weather Service) to discuss the issues that Utah ski industry faces. They discuss the following issues: overcrowding in the mountains, the impact of multi-mountain passes on lift lines and parking, and Utah’s changing climate. Why I Don’t Think It’s Going Bust It’s true that Utah’s most uncrowded days are behind it. The times that fixed-grip lifts helped Utah hold onto powder for days are over. articles.title: Private Plane Skids Off Runway At Colorado Ski Town Airport
articles.description: A private plane skidded about 300 yards off the runaway at Telluride Regional Airport as it was landing on Tuesday, January 13th.
articles.content: TELLURIDE, Colorado – A private plane skidded about 300 yards off the runaway at Telluride Regional Airport as it was landing on Tuesday, January 13th. According to the San Miguel County Sheriff’s Office , the plane, which was a Cessna Citation X, was landing at approximately 12:15pm when it skidded off the runway. The pilot informed deputies that a strong, gusting-crosswind hit the plane right after its wheels touched down. It eventually came to a rest on collapsed landing gear, though there was no fire or smoke. Three occupants were on board, including two pilots and one passenger, at the time of the crash. All occupants were able to exit on their own without injury. Damage to the plane included its left wing and nose wheel. The NTSB and FAA will be further running the investigation. With travel websites and cheap air-fare it is possible to make a European ski vacation come true. So as the prices skyrocket Vail is starting to seem more overrated with lift tickets reaching over $300 and notoriously long lift lines. With those numbers skiing locally at Vail would cost about $1,128. Taking a round trip flight from Vail to Bulgaria with lodging included can cost as low as $682. articles.title: Chasing Strava Speed Records At Jackson Hole
articles.description: Professional skiers Jim Ryan and Madison Ostergren decided to chase the fastest Strava segments without the perfect conditions.
articles.content: Anyone who frequently uses Strava knows the desire to capture as many KOMs or QOMs as possible. For those who don’t know, KOMs and QOMs mark the fastest athlete on a specific route, whether it’s for cycling, running, or, most appealing to us, skiing. Most KOMs are captured in perfect conditions. In skiing, that usually means perfectly groomed or powdery runs with wind at your back and fantastic visibility. Professional skiers Jim Ryan and Madison Ostergren decided to chase the fastest Strava segments without the perfect conditions, hunting the KOMs on expert, mogul only terrain. With conditions like that, capturing top times would be near impossible, but they still set out to see what they could do. For those wondering, they did set pretty strict rules for their attempts.
